newsitem.title: UK: UK Labour won't put VAT on books - Blair.
newsitem.headline: UK Labour won't put VAT on books - Blair.

text.p: Labour leader Tony Blair said on Tuesday that his party would not put value added tax (VAT) on books if it won Britain's coming election.
"That wouldn't be sensible at all," Blair said during a wide-ranging question and answer session with businessmen.
He also said Labour had no plans to change inheritance tax legislation as it applied to small businesses.
Blair stressed the importance of a sound and stable economic policy, warning that Britain would be swiftly "crucified" by the international financial markets if it tried to go it alone.
"We can't do with another boom and bust," Balir said.
He repeatedly told his audience that Labour would not promise anything it could not deliver, but he said he would not be knocked off course in trying to achieve five fundamental objectives:
-- Creating an education system for the 21st century
-- Laying the foundations of a modern welfare state

-- Transforming relations between Labour and business so that at the election after the coming poll no-one will even think of questioning whether the Conservatives or Labour are the pro-business party.
-- Making a fresh and different start in Europe.
